bestBHT.bht: Jesus, along with two malefactors, was led to be put to death. Even though Jesus was innocent, being grouped with these evildoers deepened the shame He bore on the cross. It conveyed the false notion that He was just as guilty and deserving of death as they were. The crucifixion, a punishment reserved for the lowest and most contemptible individuals, magnified the disgrace Jesus endured, underscoring the magnitude of His suffering.

Marvin Vincent: The deep damnation of his taking off.
Let her who would be rid of him, devise His speedy taking off.
Philip Schaff: Luke 23:32. Two others. The sympathy seems to have been, not for them, but for Him alone.
Led with him. Luke alone narrates this.
Archibald T. Robertson: Were led. Imperfect passive of αγω, were being led."
To be put to death. First aorist passive infinitive of αναιρεω, old verb, to take up, to take away, to kill.
John Gill: Not that Christ was one, though indeed he was looked upon and treated as one by the Jews.
For the greater ignominy and reproach of Christ, that it might be thought he was equally a malefactor, and as deserving of death as they.
The death of the cross, which was the death the Romans put slaves, thieves, and robbers, and the worst and basest of men to.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 23:32, two malefactors were led with Jesus to be put to death. This is significant because while Jesus was innocent, He was grouped with these evildoers and treated as one of them. The inclusion of these malefactors emphasizes the deep shame and ignominy that Jesus endured on the cross, as He was wrongly perceived and treated as deserving of death. It is important to note that Jesus' crucifixion was a death reserved for the lowest and vilest of individuals, highlighting the extent of the humiliation He faced.

In this passage, two malefactors were led along with Jesus to be put to death. Though Jesus was innocent, He was unjustly associated with these evildoers, highlighting the utter shame and dishonor He endured on the cross. By being grouped with these criminals, Jesus was subjected to the deepest ignominy, giving the impression that He, too, deserved death. It is crucial to recognize that the crucifixion, the most degrading form of execution, was typically reserved for slaves, thieves, and the most wretched of individuals.

In this account, Jesus was led alongside two malefactors to be put to death. While Jesus was innocent, being associated with these evildoers added to the depth of shame He faced on the cross. It conveyed the false perception that Jesus was equally guilty and deserving of death. The crucifixion, a means of execution reserved for slaves, thieves, and the most despicable individuals, further emphasized the extent of the disgrace Jesus endured in His crucifixion.

Jesus, along with two malefactors, was led to be put to death. Even though Jesus was innocent, being grouped with these evildoers deepened the shame He bore on the cross. It conveyed the false notion that He was just as guilty and deserving of death as they were. The crucifixion, a punishment reserved for the lowest and most contemptible individuals, magnified the disgrace Jesus endured, underscoring the magnitude of His suffering.

In Luke 23:32, Jesus was led to be put to death alongside two malefactors, igniting intense shame upon Him on the cross. This association falsely portrayed Jesus as equally deserving of death, amplifying the depths of His humiliation. His crucifixion stood as the ultimate degradation, typically reserved for the vilest criminals and lowest societal outcasts. This stark contrast between Jesus, the sinless Son of God, and the malefactors underscores the tremendous sacrifice He willingly embraced to rescue humanity from its sin.
